Thanks.\n\n---\n\n- If you've already signed a CLA, it's possible we don't have your GitHub username or you're using a different email address.  Check [your existing CLA data](https://cla.developers.google.com/clas) and verify that your [email is set on your git commits](https://help.github.com/articles/setting-your-email-in-git/).\n- If your company signed a CLA, they designated a Point of Contact who decides which employees are authorized to participate. You may need to contact the Point of Contact for your company and ask to be added to the group of authorized contributors. If you don't know who your Point of Contact is, direct the project maintainer to go/cla#troubleshoot.\n- In order to pass this check, please resolve this problem and have the pull request author add another comment and the bot will run again.\n\n<!-- need_sender_cla -->",

    "body": "@marcphilipp Alright, I'm back, but in need of help. Splitting everything into a file tree makes #2463 extremely apparent and breaks stuff because directories show up.\r\n\r\nI'm trying to figure out how I can remove directories from showing up as task inputs _only_. It no longer makes sense for directories to be part of task inputs because a deep search is always performed with this PR, meaning if there are files under the directory, they will be included.\r\n\r\nI tried a [naive implementation by filtering](https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/6019/files#diff-edfeef99fdd02fa0f9b1fdd18d7ed580), but that's obviously the wrong way to do it because it will be bad for performance and it breaks relative path sensitivity.     "body": "In order to fix #4166 I would suggest to change `RebuildIncrementalTaskInputs`, so it doesn't use the `TaskProperties` but instead uses `FileCollectionFingerprint.getFingerprints()` (`CurrentTaskExecution.getInputFingerprints()`). All the fingerprints would then be reported as added. That has the advantage that we don't need to walk the file system again, since we already have the fingerprints of the input files.\r\n\r\nPlease remove the changes related to `optional` and input file validation from this PR or create a new one.",

    "created_at": "2017-03-29T16:01:39Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-03-29T16:01:39Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I added test coverage to show the _is_ state without more additional operations. It shows the missing project configuration context in the case of nested configurations.\r\n\r\nI added a build operations for the nested project configuarations (via `Project.allprojects()`, `Project.subprojects()`, `Project.project()`). This is done directly inside `DefaultProject` as the config actions are directly excuted from there. I wonder if we should add a _ProjectConfigurationService_ as intermediate step and wrap that in a _BuildOperationProjectConfigurationService_. I.e., instead of calling `ConfigureUtil.configure()` directly, do that through such a service. Injecting an additional service into `DefaultProject` however seems to be rather clumsy as we have to go through `ProjectFactory` and so on. Maybe `GradleInternal` could provide the service.\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/1033/commits/7b58a3ed0c9ca64693ba7be826b5d5d7c9323842#diff-421664408d352dfb47b0785a797100bf\r\n\r\nIn the case of init script plugins: It is still not obvious where the `apply` comes from, as the actual configuration happens not where it is declared. This is a case for #1700 to be addressed there.",

    "created_at": "2017-03-30T09:33:32Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-03-30T09:33:32Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I introduced `DomainObjectConfigurator` as a configuration service which is then used to hook in build operations:\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/75838fcd289bae99458d72523a2cc66e75336ee3/subprojects/core/src/main/java/org/gradle/internal/configuration/DomainObjectConfigurator.java\r\n\r\nThe `BuildOperationDomainObjectConfigurator` (delegator) wraps every config action on a domain object that implements `HasBuildOperationContext` (currently only `ProjectInternal`). We can use that to turn other configurations into build operations as well easily (e.g. dependencies, buildscript, ...).\r\n\r\nThe parameter `@Nullable final String callerContextInformation` in the signatures of `DomainObjectConfigurator` probably will be replaced by an interface (or removed). It depends on how we continue with the topic of providing more context to a build operation in general (#1700). I think for this PR we can probably keep it like this as a first step.",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2017-03-29T16:01:39Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-03-29T16:01:39Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I added test coverage to show the _is_ state without more additional operations. It shows the missing project configuration context in the case of nested configurations.\r\n\r\nI added a build operations for the nested project configuarations (via `Project.allprojects()`, `Project.subprojects()`, `Project.project()`). This is done directly inside `DefaultProject` as the config actions are directly excuted from there. I wonder if we should add a _ProjectConfigurationService_ as intermediate step and wrap that in a _BuildOperationProjectConfigurationService_. I.e., instead of calling `ConfigureUtil.configure()` directly, do that through such a service. Injecting an additional service into `DefaultProject` however seems to be rather clumsy as we have to go through `ProjectFactory` and so on. Maybe `GradleInternal` could provide the service.\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/1033/commits/7b58a3ed0c9ca64693ba7be826b5d5d7c9323842#diff-421664408d352dfb47b0785a797100bf\r\n\r\nIn the case of init script plugins: It is still not obvious where the `apply` comes from, as the actual configuration happens not where it is declared. This is a case for #1700 to be addressed there.",

    "created_at": "2017-03-30T09:33:32Z",
    "updated_at": "2017-03-30T09:33:32Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I introduced `DomainObjectConfigurator` as a configuration service which is then used to hook in build operations:\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/75838fcd289bae99458d72523a2cc66e75336ee3/subprojects/core/src/main/java/org/gradle/internal/configuration/DomainObjectConfigurator.java\r\n\r\nThe `BuildOperationDomainObjectConfigurator` (delegator) wraps every config action on a domain object that implements `HasBuildOperationContext` (currently only `ProjectInternal`). We can use that to turn other configurations into build operations as well easily (e.g. dependencies, buildscript, ...).\r\n\r\nThe parameter `@Nullable final String callerContextInformation` in the signatures of `DomainObjectConfigurator` probably will be replaced by an interface (or removed). It depends on how we continue with the topic of providing more context to a build operation in general (#1700). I think for this PR we can probably keep it like this as a first step.",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "updated_at": "2017-03-30T09:33:32Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I introduced `DomainObjectConfigurator` as a configuration service which is then used to hook in build operations:\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/blob/75838fcd289bae99458d72523a2cc66e75336ee3/subprojects/core/src/main/java/org/gradle/internal/configuration/DomainObjectConfigurator.java\r\n\r\nThe `BuildOperationDomainObjectConfigurator` (delegator) wraps every config action on a domain object that implements `HasBuildOperationContext` (currently only `ProjectInternal`). We can use that to turn other configurations into build operations as well easily (e.g. dependencies, buildscript, ...).\r\n\r\nThe parameter `@Nullable final String callerContextInformation` in the signatures of `DomainObjectConfigurator` probably will be replaced by an interface (or removed). It depends on how we continue with the topic of providing more context to a build operation in general (#1700). I think for this PR we can probably keep it like this as a first step.",

    "updated_at": "2017-03-29T16:01:39Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I added test coverage to show the _is_ state without more additional operations. It shows the missing project configuration context in the case of nested configurations.\r\n\r\nI added a build operations for the nested project configuarations (via `Project.allprojects()`, `Project.subprojects()`, `Project.project()`). This is done directly inside `DefaultProject` as the config actions are directly excuted from there. I wonder if we should add a _ProjectConfigurationService_ as intermediate step and wrap that in a _BuildOperationProjectConfigurationService_. I.e., instead of calling `ConfigureUtil.configure()` directly, do that through such a service. Injecting an additional service into `DefaultProject` however seems to be rather clumsy as we have to go through `ProjectFactory` and so on. Maybe `GradleInternal` could provide the service.\r\nhttps://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/1033/commits/7b58a3ed0c9ca64693ba7be826b5d5d7c9323842#diff-421664408d352dfb47b0785a797100bf\r\n\r\nIn the case of init script plugins: It is still not obvious where the `apply` comes from, as the actual configuration happens not where it is declared. This is a case for #1700 to be addressed there.",

    "created_at": "2015-11-16T16:53:13Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-16T16:53:13Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "@riemenschneider Thank you for the work you did so far. I took a closer look at this pull request and here are my comments:\n- Annotate new fields in TestNGOptions with @Incubating. This is what we always do for new stuff in the API. \n- Use primitive boolean type for new fields in TestNGOptions. This is what we normally do in other places and it will make the code a little bit safer and simpler. Let's default to what was previously used for backward compatibility (both values false when not explicitly set to true)\n- One integration test case per new option should be perfectly enough. These tests are very slow, especially when executed for multiple versions. You could try to combine similar test cases and rely on unit tests to verify default values and corner cases.\n- Last two test cases for preserveOrder and groupByInstances are almost identical. It would be good to use specific [minimal fixture](http://xunitpatterns.com/Minimal%20Fixture.html) so that both tests clearly document what each option is about. If this comment sounds too vague please let me know and I'll be happy to help you to come up with better test cases.\n- Remove TextUtil.toPlatformLineSeparators when checking output in the integration test. This causes tests to fail on Windows because output is normalized to use Unix style newlines.\n- Update user guide under \"23.13\". A new section called something like \"Controlling test execution order in TestNG\" should do the trick.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pioterj/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/pioterj/received_events",

      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-25T13:39:40Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-25T13:39:40Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "@riemenschneider Thank you. There are two major problems with the corrections you made:\n- New integration tests fail when executed against multiple TestNG versions. Note that the \"org.gradle.integtest.multiversion\" property needs to be set to \"all\" in order to run tests against multiple versions\n- Documentation can't be generated. You can verify that using command \"gradlew :docs:docs\"\n\nAlso, I noticed that you made a comment in the user guide that Gradle's overrides TestNG defaults in regards to preserving test execution order. This is not our intention. The documentation says that tests run in the order they are found in the XML file by default (when preserve-order attribute is not set). However when I checked org.testng.TestNG class which Gradle uses to run tests it explicitly sets this attribute to false. In case the defaults vary between TestNG versions we should reconsider how these new values are set. It would be great if you could do some research into that. In general we want to avoid introducing changes that are not backward compatible. If someone uses specific TestNG version with Gradle now we don't want test execution order to change when when they upgrade Gradle. \n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
  {

    "body": "I have split up the integration into two separate integration tests for preserve-order and group-by-instances and created separate coverages for them. There I did the same trick for the preserve-order coverage which is ['6.9.4', NEWEST] if the JVM supports Java 7 and empty otherwise.\n\nDo we have any common handling for the situation that an option is used with a TestNG version not supporting it?     "created_at": "2015-12-02T12:36:01Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-12-02T12:36:01Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "What is the default behaviour of TestNG from your point of view?\n\nOn the one hand you can configure the test suite programmatically by using org.testng.TestNG API. Using that way a NoSuchMethodException is more or less the way TestNG is handling the situation (the method is not there and if you try to call it using reflection, you get a NSME).\n\nOn the other hand TestNG is mostly configured using a testng.xml file and if this XML configuration contains an unknown attribute, it is simply (and silently) ignored.\n\nI have currently implemented the first way (try to set the option and if that fails AND the option is true, throw the caught exception) in order to inform the user about the fact, that is was not possible to run the test suite as it was specified. Unfortunately I am not able to pass the option to TestNG and propagate failures since there are not methods for passing the options.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Understood, wasn't sure if the TestNG API was static or if options were passing in as a map of string or something similar. In this case we would have to handle the NSME, the question is whether we fail the build or not. I don't have super strong feelings on this either way but in general I'm not a huge fan of silently ignoring errors. I think returning an error indicating to the user that the option isn't available on the version of TestNG they are using seems reasonable. I would make sure we include this information in the documentation (JavaDocs, DSL reference, etc), indicating that these options are only applicable to certain versions of TestNG.\n",

    "created_at": "2015-11-16T16:53:13Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-16T16:53:13Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "@riemenschneider Thank you for the work you did so far. I took a closer look at this pull request and here are my comments:\n- Annotate new fields in TestNGOptions with @Incubating. This is what we always do for new stuff in the API. \n- Use primitive boolean type for new fields in TestNGOptions. This is what we normally do in other places and it will make the code a little bit safer and simpler. Let's default to what was previously used for backward compatibility (both values false when not explicitly set to true)\n- One integration test case per new option should be perfectly enough. These tests are very slow, especially when executed for multiple versions. You could try to combine similar test cases and rely on unit tests to verify default values and corner cases.\n- Last two test cases for preserveOrder and groupByInstances are almost identical. It would be good to use specific [minimal fixture](http://xunitpatterns.com/Minimal%20Fixture.html) so that both tests clearly document what each option is about. If this comment sounds too vague please let me know and I'll be happy to help you to come up with better test cases.\n- Remove TextUtil.toPlatformLineSeparators when checking output in the integration test. This causes tests to fail on Windows because output is normalized to use Unix style newlines.\n- Update user guide under \"23.13\". A new section called something like \"Controlling test execution order in TestNG\" should do the trick.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2015-11-25T13:39:40Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-25T13:39:40Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "@riemenschneider Thank you. There are two major problems with the corrections you made:\n- New integration tests fail when executed against multiple TestNG versions. Note that the \"org.gradle.integtest.multiversion\" property needs to be set to \"all\" in order to run tests against multiple versions\n- Documentation can't be generated. You can verify that using command \"gradlew :docs:docs\"\n\nAlso, I noticed that you made a comment in the user guide that Gradle's overrides TestNG defaults in regards to preserving test execution order. This is not our intention. The documentation says that tests run in the order they are found in the XML file by default (when preserve-order attribute is not set). However when I checked org.testng.TestNG class which Gradle uses to run tests it explicitly sets this attribute to false. In case the defaults vary between TestNG versions we should reconsider how these new values are set. It would be great if you could do some research into that. In general we want to avoid introducing changes that are not backward compatible. If someone uses specific TestNG version with Gradle now we don't want test execution order to change when when they upgrade Gradle. \n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-12-02T12:36:01Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-12-02T12:36:01Z",
    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "What is the default behaviour of TestNG from your point of view?\n\nOn the one hand you can configure the test suite programmatically by using org.testng.TestNG API. Using that way a NoSuchMethodException is more or less the way TestNG is handling the situation (the method is not there and if you try to call it using reflection, you get a NSME).\n\nOn the other hand TestNG is mostly configured using a testng.xml file and if this XML configuration contains an unknown attribute, it is simply (and silently) ignored.\n\nI have currently implemented the first way (try to set the option and if that fails AND the option is true, throw the caught exception) in order to inform the user about the fact, that is was not possible to run the test suite as it was specified. Unfortunately I am not able to pass the option to TestNG and propagate failures since there are not methods for passing the options.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "author_association": "CONTRIBUTOR",
    "body": "Understood, wasn't sure if the TestNG API was static or if options were passing in as a map of string or something similar. In this case we would have to handle the NSME, the question is whether we fail the build or not. I don't have super strong feelings on this either way but in general I'm not a huge fan of silently ignoring errors. I think returning an error indicating to the user that the option isn't available on the version of TestNG they are using seems reasonable. I would make sure we include this information in the documentation (JavaDocs, DSL reference, etc), indicating that these options are only applicable to certain versions of TestNG.\n",

  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/comments/154221212",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154221212,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyMTIxMg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "melix",
      "id": 316357,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjMxNjM1Nw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/316357?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/melix",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },
  {
    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/comments/154225252",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154225252",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154225252,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyNTI1Mg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "big-guy",
      "id": 5387972,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjUzODc5NzI=",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars0.githubusercontent.com/u/5387972?v=4",

    "created_at": "2015-11-05T23:09:06Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T23:09:06Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "+1 for moving the task to a \"public\" package.  We probably want to support users being able to say `tasks.withType(ApiJar) { /* configure */ }`, which means ApiJar needs to be public.\n\n-1 for moving the supporting classes to a non-internal package.  It makes determining what we consider public a lot harder, even if the classes are package private.  We've been trying to move internal-but-not-in-an-internal-package into internal packages over time.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "created_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I'm also -1 on using package privacy for internal classes. I think we give\nup more than we gain. I'd be +1 for more consistency with how we structure\nour internal packages.\nI strongly recommend not making this change without explicit go ahead from\nAdam.\n\nOn Thu, 5 Nov 2015, 3:51 p.m. Cdric Champeau notifications@github.com\nwrote:\n\n> I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference\n> between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same\n> as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually\n> surprising that no test fails after removing JavaBaseModule, because it\n> is used in validation).\n> \n> As for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this\n> mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited\n> by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A\n> in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking.\n> \n> But I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of\n> flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw\n> modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this.\n> In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should\n> be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users\n> might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that\n> it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken\n> in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package\n> private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it\n> using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n> \n> Last but not least, @Incubating in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's\n> an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember\n> any class marked as @Incubating which has been removed. On the other\n> hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package.\n> And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain internal, to\n> me, it becomes public API.\n> \n> \n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub\n> https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/comments/154221212",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154221212,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyMTIxMg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "melix",
      "id": 316357,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjMxNjM1Nw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/316357?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/melix",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154221212,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyMTIxMg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "melix",
      "id": 316357,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjMxNjM1Nw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/316357?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/melix",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T23:09:06Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "+1 for moving the task to a \"public\" package.  We probably want to support users being able to say `tasks.withType(ApiJar) { /* configure */ }`, which means ApiJar needs to be public.\n\n-1 for moving the supporting classes to a non-internal package.  It makes determining what we consider public a lot harder, even if the classes are package private.  We've been trying to move internal-but-not-in-an-internal-package into internal packages over time.\n",

    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "+1 for moving the task to a \"public\" package.  We probably want to support users being able to say `tasks.withType(ApiJar) { /* configure */ }`, which means ApiJar needs to be public.\n\n-1 for moving the supporting classes to a non-internal package.  It makes determining what we consider public a lot harder, even if the classes are package private.  We've been trying to move internal-but-not-in-an-internal-package into internal packages over time.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "created_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I'm also -1 on using package privacy for internal classes. I think we give\nup more than we gain. I'd be +1 for more consistency with how we structure\nour internal packages.\nI strongly recommend not making this change without explicit go ahead from\nAdam.\n\nOn Thu, 5 Nov 2015, 3:51 p.m. Cdric Champeau notifications@github.com\nwrote:\n\n> I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference\n> between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same\n> as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually\n> surprising that no test fails after removing JavaBaseModule, because it\n> is used in validation).\n> \n> As for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this\n> mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited\n> by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A\n> in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking.\n> \n> But I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of\n> flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw\n> modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this.\n> In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should\n> be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users\n> might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that\n> it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken\n> in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package\n> private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it\n> using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n> \n> Last but not least, @Incubating in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's\n> an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember\n> any class marked as @Incubating which has been removed. On the other\n> hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package.\n> And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain internal, to\n> me, it becomes public API.\n> \n> \n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub\n> https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/comments/154221212",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154221212,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyMTIxMg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "melix",
      "id": 316357,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjMxNjM1Nw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/316357?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/melix",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "+1 for moving the task to a \"public\" package.  We probably want to support users being able to say `tasks.withType(ApiJar) { /* configure */ }`, which means ApiJar needs to be public.\n\n-1 for moving the supporting classes to a non-internal package.  It makes determining what we consider public a lot harder, even if the classes are package private.  We've been trying to move internal-but-not-in-an-internal-package into internal packages over time.\n",

    "created_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-06T04:53:10Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I'm also -1 on using package privacy for internal classes. I think we give\nup more than we gain. I'd be +1 for more consistency with how we structure\nour internal packages.\nI strongly recommend not making this change without explicit go ahead from\nAdam.\n\nOn Thu, 5 Nov 2015, 3:51 p.m. Cdric Champeau notifications@github.com\nwrote:\n\n> I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference\n> between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same\n> as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually\n> surprising that no test fails after removing JavaBaseModule, because it\n> is used in validation).\n> \n> As for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this\n> mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited\n> by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A\n> in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking.\n> \n> But I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of\n> flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw\n> modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this.\n> In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should\n> be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users\n> might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that\n> it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken\n> in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package\n> private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it\n> using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n> \n> Last but not least, @Incubating in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's\n> an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember\n> any class marked as @Incubating which has been removed. On the other\n> hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package.\n> And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain internal, to\n> me, it becomes public API.\n> \n> \n> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub\n> https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null

    "url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/comments/154221212",
    "html_url": "https://github.com/gradle/gradle/pull/541#issuecomment-154221212",
    "issue_url": "https://api.github.com/repos/gradle/gradle/issues/541",
    "id": 154221212,
    "node_id": "MDEyOklzc3VlQ29tbWVudDE1NDIyMTIxMg==",
    "user": {
      "login": "melix",
      "id": 316357,
      "node_id": "MDQ6VXNlcjMxNjM1Nw==",
      "avatar_url": "https://avatars2.githubusercontent.com/u/316357?v=4",
      "gravatar_id": "",
      "url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix",
      "html_url": "https://github.com/melix",
      "followers_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/followers",
      "following_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/following{/other_user}",
      "gists_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/gists{/gist_id}",
      "starred_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/starred{/owner}{/repo}",
      "subscriptions_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/subscriptions",
      "organizations_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/orgs",
      "repos_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/repos",
      "events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/events{/privacy}",
      "received_events_url": "https://api.github.com/users/melix/received_events",
      "type": "User",
      "site_admin": false
    },
    "created_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T22:51:34Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "I have no strong objection on the renames (in fact, there is a difference between allowed and exported: allowed packages are not necessarily the same as exported ones. Take the example of the java-base module. It is actually surprising that no test fails after removing `JavaBaseModule`, because it is used in validation).\n\nAs for package private classes, I am -1 on this. I don't like this mechanism. For me package privacy is broken. Should have it been inherited by sub-packages, or through class hierarchy (A in package pkg1, B extends A in pkg2, C extends A in pkg1), I would have maybe a different thinking. \n\nBut I _really_ like the separation of internal package. It gives a lot of flexibility, and it is actually what is going to be publicized with Jigsaw modules. I am not sure we're not moving in the right direction doing this. In general, I consider that almost all types can be public, and it should be documented when to use or not to use one class. In particular, users might want to use internal classes. I did it in the past, and the fact that it's in a package named \"internal\" makes you aware that it might be broken in the future, but you are aware. On the other hand, if it had been package private, I wouldn't be able to do it, or I would just have worked around it using a class in the same package. Which is dirty.\n\nLast but not least, `@Incubating` in Gradle has a tradition of saying \"it's an experimental API\". Yet, they belong to the public API. I don't remember any class marked as `@Incubating` which has been removed. On the other hand, I feel ok to remove, rename or move a class in an internal package. And as soon as it moves into a package that doesn't contain `internal`, to me, it becomes public API.\n",
    "performed_via_github_app": null
  },

    "updated_at": "2015-11-05T23:09:06Z",
    "author_association": "MEMBER",
    "body": "+1 for moving the task to a \"public\" package.  We probably want to support users being able to say `tasks.withType(ApiJar) { /* configure */ }`, which means ApiJar needs to be public.\n\n-1 for moving the supporting classes to a non-internal package.  It makes determining what we consider public a lot harder, even if the classes are package private.  We've been trying to move internal-but-not-in-an-internal-package into internal packages over time.\n",
